bibl.title: Letter from George M. Wratten to Emilie Lawrence Reed, April 1, 1912

div1.p: Wratten sends Emilie Lawrence Reed transliterations of [song?] titles.

div1.head: Letter from George M. Wratten to Emilie Lawrence Reed, April 1, 1912
div1.opener:
Kansas City Mo
April 1st 12
Mrs. Walter Reed,
“The Cairo,”
Washington, D. C,
Dear Madam;
div1.p:
Your letter of near
20th was forwarded to me
from Fort Sill.

I am only too pleased to
furnish you the information
you desire.

“Do not cry” To-e-chu-dah
“I have not any”
Toe-thle nash-e-dah
“Call me”
She ong - zhee
I have never heard the
Apache squaws use
words in the songs they
sing their children,
just simply a sort of croon,
as
Ah - ah - ah - ah-
Oo - Oo - Oo - Oo
repeated over and over again
in a sort of sing, song
tone.

I will be very glad to
furnish you any other information that
I can, should you desire it.

I knew Dr. Reed well and
was a great admirer of his.
I am in St Josephs
Hospital here now, but
a letter addressed to
Fort Sill Okla will always
reach me,
